content.description:
This one actually looks alright. It is the second of what might be considered climbable boulders on the ridge above the Bad Apple trailhead.

My idea is that you would bunch your shit up on that low jug with a heel hook, then rock up on the crimps, and topout. And hope like hell the whole thing doesn't fall on top of you.
content.location:
Gain the ridge, and walk for twenty minutes.

40.742903, -111.553697

content.description:
High up on the ridge above Bad Apple Trailhead, as high as you can go, there is a slab with a crack running through it. It isn't taller than 8 feet.

Exclusively for the truly desperate.

May not have been done before. I know I couldn't be bothered.
content.protection: Protect yourself by not climbing this terrible thing
content.location:
As above. Start on Bad Apple trailhead, gain the ridge. Hike until you see this boulder.

40.743322, -111.554192

content.description:
The better of the two boulders, and worth spending a moment on.

I found a few lines here. They are not so forced.

The main line, as far as I'm concerned, is to start sitting down and left. I used two thin crimps to start. Then fire up left hand to a thin tweaky crimp. Set your feet, and do a big iron cross out to the right to a cool sloper jug. Then finish on incut guano jugs to a nice topout.

There are two other obvious lines, which I will try to indicate on the photo, which are easier, but also worth doing.

The face is big enough that you could find more variations than on the upper boulder. Maybe there's even a nice dyno from low holds to the top? I didn't do that.

May have been first done by Sean Faulkner. I saw this one shared by him a couple years ago, but the page is gone now. If there is some issue, please let me know.

The lesser of the two boulders, I'd say, but you can find some fun movement here.

There is no single obvious line. I found four places to start, and four places to finish, and all ways to do it are between 2 and 5 moves.

My favorite way to do it was to start on a right hand sidepull and a left hand sidepull, stand on a thin foot, and cut left. I think topping out on the large shelf to the left using just the shelf is actually pretty good movement.

Don't expect much: it's all very forced.
content.protection: 2 pads. Pants to avoid getting torn up by the spiky plants.
content.location: Just above trail as you are walking up.
